sen.j: 彦根藩（ひこねはん）は、近江国の北部を領有した藩。
sen.e: Hikone Domain refers to a domain which possessed the northern part of Omi Province.
Hikone Domain refers to a domain which possessed the northern part of Omi Province.
Hikone Domain refers to a domain which possessed the northern part of Omi Province.

sen.j: 藩庁は彦根城（滋賀県彦根市）に置かれた（入封当初は佐和山城）。
sen.e: A government building of domain was located at Hikone-jo Castle (Hikone City, Shiga Prefecture) (at Sawayama-jo Castle in the beginning of entering into a new domain).
The government building of the domain was located at Hikone-jo Castle (Hikone City, Shiga Prefecture) (at Sawayama-jo Castle at the beginning of the domain.)
sen.cmt: 入封とは「土地を与えられその領地に入る事」ですが、単語リストの訳をtrans1のようにそのまま使うと、誰が入ったのかわからず訳が成り立ちません。「藩が成立した当初」という訳の方が良いと思います。
sen.e: The government building of the domain was located at Hikone-jo Castle (Hikone City, Shiga Prefecture) (at Sawayama-jo Castle at the beginning of the domain.)

sen.j: 藩主は譜代大名筆頭の井伊氏。
sen.e: The lord of domain was the Ii clan, the first on a list of fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family).
The lord of domain was the Ii clan, the first on the list of fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family.)
The lord of domain was the Ii clan, the first on the list of fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family.)

sen.j: 支藩として一時、支藩があった。
sen.e: As a branch domain, the Hikone Domain had a branch domain.
It once had Hikone-Shinden Domain as its branch domain.
sen.cmt: Wikipedia本文では「支藩として一時、彦根新田藩があった。」のようです。
sen.e: It once had Hikone-Shinden Domain as its branch domain.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）上野国高崎城主で12万石を領していた徳川四天王の一人・井伊直政が関ヶ原の戦いの戦功により18万石に加増され、石田三成の居城であった佐和山城に入封して佐和山藩を立藩した。
sen.e: In 1600, Naomasa II who was a lord of Takasaki-jo Castle in Kozuke Province with properties bearing 120,000 koku (1 koku was about 180 liter; an old unit showing volume) and was one of Tokugawa-shitenno (four generals serving Tokugawa Ieyasu), received an additional properties bearing 60,000 koku due to his distinguished war service in the Battle of Sekigahara, entered into the Sawayama-jo Castle which used to be a residential castle of Mitsunari ISHIDA, and established the Sawayama Domain.

In 1600, Naomasa II who was the lord of Takasaki-jo Castle in Kozuke Province with properties bearing 120,000 koku (1 koku was about 180 liter; an old unit showing volume) and was one of Tokugawa-shitenno (four generals serving Tokugawa Ieyasu), received an additional properties bearing 60,000 koku due to his distinguished war service in the Battle of Sekigahara, entered into the Sawayama-jo Castle which used to be the residential castle of Mitsunari ISHIDA, and established the Sawayama Domain.

In 1600, Naomasa II who was the lord of Takasaki-jo Castle in Kozuke Province with properties bearing 120,000 koku (1 koku was about 180 liter; an old unit showing volume) and was one of Tokugawa-shitenno (four generals serving Tokugawa Ieyasu), received an additional properties bearing 60,000 koku due to his distinguished war service in the Battle of Sekigahara, entered into the Sawayama-jo Castle which used to be the residential castle of Mitsunari ISHIDA, and established the Sawayama Domain.

sen.j: 直政は賊将・石田三成の居城を嫌い、琵琶湖の湖岸の磯山に新城建設を計画したが、建設に着手する前に戦傷が元で慶長7年（1602年）に死去した。
sen.e: Namasa disliked the residential castle of Mitsunari ISHIDA who was a rebel general, and planned a construction of new castle at Isoyama at the lakefront of Lake Biwa, but died of war injury in 1602 before starting the construction.

Naomasa disliked the residential castle of Mitsunari ISHIDA who was a rebel general, and planned a construction of new castle at Isoyama at the lakefront of Lake Biwa, but died of war injury in 1602 before starting the construction.
sen.cmt: 直政の綴りを修正しました。
sen.e: Naomasa disliked the residential castle of Mitsunari ISHIDA who was a rebel general, and planned a construction of new castle at Isoyama at the lakefront of Lake Biwa, but died of war injury in 1602 before starting the construction.

sen.j: 嫡子・井伊直継が相続すると現在彦根城が存する彦根山に新城の建設が開始された。
sen.e: When his legitimate child, Naotsugu II, succeeded, the construction of new castle started at Mt. Hikone where the Hikone-jo Castle exists at present.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When his legitimate child Naotsugu II succeeded, the construction of new castle started in Mt. Hikone where the Hikone-jo Castle exists at present.
When his legitimate child Naotsugu II succeeded, the construction of new castle started in Mt. Hikone where the Hikone-jo Castle exists at present.

sen.j: 慶長11年（1606年）完成し彦根城に入城した。
sen.e: In 1606, the new castle was completed, and Naotsugu II entered the Hikone-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1606, the new castle was completed and Naotsugu II entered the Hikone-jo Castle.
In 1606, the new castle was completed and Naotsugu II entered the Hikone-jo Castle.

sen.j: 元和 (日本)元年（1615年）直継は病弱で大坂の役に参陣出来なかったことを理由に、直勝と名を改め上野国安中藩に3万石を分知され移封となった。
sen.e: In 1615, Naotsugu who changed his name to Naokatsu by reason that he could not participate in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka) due to sickliness was transferred to the Annaka Domain in Kozuke Province with subdivided properties bearing 30,000 koku.

In 1615, Naotsugu changed his name to Naokatsu and was transferred to the Annaka Domain in Kozuke Province with subdivided properties bearing 30,000 koku because he could not participate in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka) due to sickliness.
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように修正しました。
sen.e: In 1615, Naotsugu changed his name to Naokatsu and was transferred to the Annaka Domain in Kozuke Province with subdivided properties bearing 30,000 koku because he could not participate in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka) due to sickliness.

sen.j: 代わって参陣し活躍した弟の井伊直孝が藩主となった。
sen.e: His younger brother, Naotaka II, who participated in Osaka no Eki on behalf of Naokatsu and played an active role became a lort of domain.
His younger brother Naotaka II, who participated in Osaka no Eki on behalf of Naokatsu and played an active role, became the lord of the domain.
His younger brother Naotaka II, who participated in Osaka no Eki on behalf of Naokatsu and played an active role, became the lord of the domain.

sen.j: この時点で直継の2代藩主としての履歴は抹消され、直孝を2代とした。
sen.e: The record of Naotsugu as the second lord of domain was deleted at this point of time, and Naotaka was recorded as the second lord of domain.
The record of Naotsugu as the second lord of domain was deleted at this point of time, and Naotaka was recorded as the second lord of domain.
The record of Naotsugu as the second lord of domain was deleted at this point of time, and Naotaka was recorded as the second lord of domain.

sen.j: 直孝は幕閣の中枢としての活躍を認められ、元和元年・元和3年（1617年）・寛永10年（1633年）の3度にわたりそれぞれ5万石の加増がなされた。
sen.e: Naotaka whose activities as a key person among the cabinet officials of the Shogunate were recognized was granted three-time additional properties bearing 50,000 koku each in 1615, 1617 and 1633.
Naotaka's activities as a key cabinet official of the Shogunate were recognized and he was granted three-time additional properties bearing 50,000 koku each in 1615, 1617 and 1633.
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように修正しました。
sen.e: Naotaka's activities as a key cabinet official of the Shogunate were recognized and he was granted three-time additional properties bearing 50,000 koku each in 1615, 1617 and 1633.

sen.j: よって30万石の大封を得る大名となった。
sen.e: As a result, Naotaka became daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) possessing large properties bearing 300,000 koku.
As a result, Naotaka became daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) possessing large properties bearing 300,000 koku.
As a result, Naotaka became daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) possessing large properties bearing 300,000 koku.

sen.j: 更に天領の城付米預かりとして2万石（知行高換算5万石）を付与され35万石の格式を得るに至った。
sen.e: Moreover, he was granted properties bearing 20,000 koku (equivalent to 50,000 koku when converting into Chigyo daka (a stipend in terms of rice production of the fief) as custodian of rice to the castle of tengyo (a shogunal demesne), and finally received a social status having properties bearing 350,000 koku.

Moreover, he was granted properties bearing 20,000 koku (equivalent to 50,000 koku when converted into Chigyo daka [a stipend in terms of rice production of the fief] as custodian of rice working in the castle of tenryo [a shogunal demesne,] and finally received a social status of 350,000 koku.
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。文法を修正しました。「城付」の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: Moreover, he was granted properties bearing 20,000 koku (equivalent to 50,000 koku when converted into Chigyo daka [a stipend in terms of rice production of the fief] as custodian of rice working in the castle of tenryo [a shogunal demesne,] and finally received a social status of 350,000 koku.

sen.j: 彦根藩井伊氏は幕閣の中枢を成し、酒井氏・本多氏など譜代有力大名が転封を繰り返す中、一度の転封もなく石高も譜代大名中最高であった。
sen.e: The Ii clan of Hikone Domain found fame as a key person among the cabinet officials of the Shogunate, was never transferred under circumstances where powerful fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) such as the Sakai clan, the Honda clan and so on was transferred repeatedly, and had the largest yield among fudai daimyo.

The Ii clan of Hikone Domain found fame as a key cabinet figure of the Shogunate and was never transferred to other lands while other powerful fudai daimyo such as the Sakai clan and the Honda clan were transferred one after another, and had the largest yield among fudai daimyo.
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように語順や単語を変えました。
sen.e: The Ii clan of Hikone Domain found fame as a key cabinet figure of the Shogunate and was never transferred to other lands while other powerful fudai daimyo such as the Sakai clan and the Honda clan were transferred one after another, and had the largest yield among fudai daimyo.

sen.j: また、井伊直澄・井伊直該・井伊直幸・井伊直亮・井伊直弼と5代6度（直該が2度、直孝が大老になったかどうかは賛否両論である）の大老に就いた。
sen.e: And, Tairo (chief minister) was assumed by the Ii clan six times for five generations such as Naozumi II, Naomori II, Naohide II, Naoaki II and Naosuke II (there are arguments for and against a theory that Naomori assumed Tairo twice, and Naotaka assumed Tairo).

And, Tairo (chief minister) was assumed by the Ii clan six times for five generations such as Naozumi II, Naomori II, Naohide II, Naoaki II and Naosuke II (there are arguments for and against the theory that Naomori assumed Tairo twice, and Naotaka assumed Tairo).

And, Tairo (chief minister) was assumed by the Ii clan six times for five generations such as Naozumi II, Naomori II, Naohide II, Naoaki II and Naosuke II (there are arguments for and against the theory that Naomori assumed Tairo twice, and Naotaka assumed Tairo).

sen.j: 文字通り譜代筆頭と言えよう。
sen.e: It is possible to say that the Ii clan was literally fudai hitto (head of fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family)).
It is possible to say that the Ii clan was literally fudai hitto (head of fudai daimyo [a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family].)
It is possible to say that the Ii clan was literally fudai hitto (head of fudai daimyo [a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family].)

sen.j: 歴代藩主の中で最も有名なのが、幕末に藩主となった直弼である。
sen.e: The most famous lord of domain among the successive lords of the domain was Naosuke who became the lord of domain at the end of Edo period.
The most famous among the successive lords of the domain was Naosuke who became the lord of domain at the end of Edo period.
sen.cmt: 不要な訳を削除しました。
sen.e: The most famous among the successive lords of the domain was Naosuke who became the lord of domain at the end of Edo period.

sen.j: 嘉永3年（1850年）兄・直亮の死去により藩主となった。
sen.e: In 1850, Naosuke became the lord of domain because his elder brother, Naoaki, died.
In 1850, Naosuke became the lord of domain because his elder brother Naoaki died.
sen.cmt: 不要なカンマを削除しました。
sen.e: In 1850, Naosuke became the lord of domain because his elder brother Naoaki died.

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年）大老に就いた。
sen.e: In 1858, Naosuke assumed Tairo.
In 1858, Naosuke assumed Tairo.
In 1858, Naosuke assumed Tairo.

sen.j: 勅許を得ず日米修好通商条約に調印、安政の大獄といわれる強権の発動を行った。
sen.e: He signed up to the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan without obtaining the Imperial sanction, and conducted the institution of vigorous action called Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate).

He signed up to the Treaty of Amity and Commerce with the United States without obtaining the Imperial sanction, and asserted ultimate authority in what is called Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate).
sen.cmt: 「強権の発動」の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: He signed up to the Treaty of Amity and Commerce with the United States without obtaining the Imperial sanction, and asserted ultimate authority in what is called Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate).

sen.j: 結果、反発を招き、万延元年（1860年）桜田門外の変で水戸藩浪士らに暗殺された。
sen.e: As a result, a backlash was provoked, and he was assassinated by roshi (masterless samurai) of Mito Domain in the Sakuradamongai Incident in 1860.
His action provoked a backlash, and he was assassinated by roshi (masterless samurai) of Mito Domain in the Sakuradamongai Incident in 1860.
sen.cmt: backlashは受け身では不自然ですので修正しました。
sen.e: His action provoked a backlash, and he was assassinated by roshi (masterless samurai) of Mito Domain in the Sakuradamongai Incident in 1860.

sen.j: 同年、藩主に就いた井伊直憲は、文久2年（1862年）直弼の罪を問われ10万石を減封された。
sen.e: In the same year, Naonori II became the lord of domain, and in 1862, his yield was reduced by 100,000 koku because he was accused of Naosuke's sins.
In the same year, Naonori II became the lord of domain, and in 1862, his yield was reduced by 100,000 koku because he was accused of Naosuke's sins.
In the same year, Naonori II became the lord of domain, and in 1862, his yield was reduced by 100,000 koku because he was accused of Naosuke's sins.

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）禁門の変での功により旧領のうち3万石を回復する。
sen.e: In 1864, Naonori regained properties bearing 30,000 koku among former territories because of his distinguished service in the Kinmon Incident.
In 1864, Naonori regained properties bearing 30,000 koku among former territories because of his distinguished service in the Kinmon Incident.
In 1864, Naonori regained properties bearing 30,000 koku among former territories because of his distinguished service in the Kinmon Incident.

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）大政奉還の後は譜代筆頭にもかかわらず新政府側に藩論を転向させた。
sen.e: After Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) in 1867, Naonori forced the new government side to go over to the opinion of domain people even though he was fudai hitto (head of fudai daimyo).
After Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) in 1867, Naonori converted the opinion of domain people into the new government side even though he was fudai hitto (head of fudai daimyo.)
sen.cmt: 新政府を藩論に転向させたのではなく「藩論を新政府寄りに転向させた」のです。
sen.e: After Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) in 1867, Naonori converted the opinion of domain people into the new government side even though he was fudai hitto (head of fudai daimyo.)

sen.j: 翌、慶応4年（1868年）の鳥羽伏見の戦いでは旧幕府軍として戦ったが離脱、後の戊辰戦争では明治政府に加わって転戦した。
sen.e: In the Battle of Toba-Fushimi in the next year, 1868, Naonori fought as the amy of old bakufu, but he seceded, and thereafter, Naonori participated in the Meiji Government and moved from place to place to fight in the Boshin Civil War.

In the Battle of Toba-Fushimi in the next year, 1868, Naonori fought as the army of old bakufu but he seceded, and thereafter, Naonori joined the Meiji Government and moved from place to place to fight in the Boshin Civil War.
sen.cmt: participatedはjoinに変えました。スペルミスを修正しました。
sen.e: In the Battle of Toba-Fushimi in the next year, 1868, Naonori fought as the army of old bakufu but he seceded, and thereafter, Naonori joined the Meiji Government and moved from place to place to fight in the Boshin Civil War.

sen.j: 賞典禄として２万石を朝廷から拝領している。
sen.e: He was granted properties bearing 20,000 koku by the Imperial Court as Shotenroku (premium).
He was granted properties bearing 20,000 koku by the Imperial Court as Shotenroku (premium).
He was granted properties bearing 20,000 koku by the Imperial Court as Shotenroku (premium).

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）廃藩置県により彦根県となった。
sen.e: In 1871, Hikone Prefecture was formed by Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).
In 1871, Hikone Prefecture was formed by Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).
In 1871, Hikone Prefecture was formed by Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

sen.j: 後、長浜県・犬上県を経て滋賀県に編入された。
sen.e: Thereafter, Hikone Prefecture was incorporated into Shiga Prefecture via Nagahama Prefecture and Inukami Prefecture.
Later, Hikone Prefecture was finally incorporated into Shiga Prefecture, after being a part of Nagahama Prefecture and Inukami Prefecture.
Later, Hikone Prefecture was finally incorporated into Shiga Prefecture, after being a part of Nagahama Prefecture and Inukami Prefecture.

sen.j: 明治17年（1884年）井伊家は伯爵となり華族に列した。
sen.e: In 1884, the Ii Family became hakushaku (a count), and was raised to the peerage.
In 1884, the Ii Family became hakushaku (a count), and was raised to the peerage.
In 1884, the Ii Family became hakushaku (a count), and was raised to the peerage.

sen.j: 支藩
sen.e: Branch domain
Branch domain
Branch domain

sen.j: 彦根新田藩
sen.e: Hikone-Shinden Domain
sen.cmt: 新田→Shinden[対訳では、"Nitta"と表記されておりますが、下記で「彦根新田藩（ひこねしんでんはん）」と記述されているので、"Shinden"に変更しました]
sen.e: Hikone-Shinden Domain
Hikone-Shinden Domain

sen.j: 彦根新田藩（ひこねしんでんはん）は江戸時代中期の正徳 (日本)4年（1714年）より享保19年（1734年）まで存した藩。
sen.e: Hikone-Shinden Domain refers to a domain which existed from 1714 to 1734 in the middle of the Edo period.
Hikone-Shinden Domain refers to a domain which existed from 1714 to 1734 in the middle of the Edo period.
Hikone-Shinden Domain refers to a domain which existed from 1714 to 1734 in the middle of the Edo period.

sen.j: 直興の十四男・井伊直定が1万石を分与され立藩。
sen.e: Naosada II, 14th son of Naooki, was granted a distribution of properties bearing 10,000 koku, and established this branch domain.
Naosada II, 14th son of Naooki, was granted a distribution of properties bearing 10,000 koku, and established this branch domain.
Naosada II, 14th son of Naooki, was granted a distribution of properties bearing 10,000 koku, and established this branch domain.

sen.j: 享保17年（1732年）直定は奏者番に就任。
sen.e: In 1732, Naosada assumed sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).
In 1732, Naosada assumed sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies.)
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を修正しました。
sen.e: In 1732, Naosada assumed sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies.)

sen.j: 享保19年、兄で8代藩主の井伊直惟の養嗣子となったため廃藩となった。
sen.e: In 1734, this branch domain was abolished because Naosada became an adopted heir of Naonobu II who was Naosada's elder brother and the 8th lord of domain.
In 1734, this branch domain was abolished because Naosada became an adopted heir of Naonobu II who was Naosada's elder brother and the 8th lord of domain.
In 1734, this branch domain was abolished because Naosada became an adopted heir of Naonobu II who was Naosada's elder brother and the 8th lord of domain.

sen.j: 直定は後、彦根藩の9代・11代（再封）藩主となっている。
sen.e: Thereafter, Naosada became the 9th and 11th (reassumption) lord of Hikone Domain.
Later, Naosada became the 9th and 11th (resumption) lord of Hikone Domain.
sen.cmt: Thereafterは不適切ですので修正しました。Reassumptionはresumptionに直しました。
sen.e: Later, Naosada became the 9th and 11th (resumption) lord of Hikone Domain.

sen.j: 木俣氏（彦根藩内1万石）維新後男爵
sen.e: The Kimata family (having properties bearing 10,000 koku in the Hikone Domain) became Baron after Meiji Restoration.
The position of Karo was succeeded by Kimata family (having properties bearing 10,000 koku in Hikone Domain) who became Baron after Meiji Restoration.
The position of Karo was succeeded by Kimata family (having properties bearing 10,000 koku in Hikone Domain) who became Baron after Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 木俣守勝－守安－守明－守長－守盈－守貞－守将－守前－守易－清閑－幹－守迪
sen.e: Morikatsu KIMATA - Yoriyasu - Moriaki - Morinaga - Morimitsu - Morisada - Morimasa - Morimae - Moriyasu - Seikan - Kan - Morimichi
sen.cmt: 「守盈」「守将」「守前」「清閑」「幹」「守迪」につきましては、仮表記です。
sen.e: Morikatsu KIMATA - Yoriyasu - Moriaki - Morinaga - Morimitsu - Morisada - Morimasa - Morimae - Moriyasu - Seikan - Kan - Morimichi
